text:
Overall, sounds good: not too intrusive.

I think that you should use the stacklevel argument of warnings.warn.

> stack_level=2 ?

Probably. Try it out.
Ping @AlexandreAbraham @GaelVaroquaux . Does it sounds good ?

> I think that you should use the stacklevel argument of warnings.warn.

stack_level=2 ?
Checking `len(all_regions_imgs)` is enough. Plus, checking `(label_maps == 0).all()` is wrong because this is a variable local to the for loop above so its value depends on the last component only.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')

text: Sure, will remove it.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')

text: You should not rely on `label_maps` here either.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')

text:
Returning an empty image was a good idea. Maybe you could do something like:

``` python
        input_img = new_img_like(maps_img, np.zeros(maps_img.shape[:3] + (0,))
```

If we do that, we will have a truly empty 4d image. However, this may break what happens next, for example if you try to plot it with prob_atlas. We have to think about it.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')

text:
> However, this may break what happens next, for example if you try to plot it with prob_atlas. We have to think about it.

I thought the same and felt that returning given image as it is would be safe and valid.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')

text:
It is not valid as you are absolutely not returning what is described in the doc. Plus, the length of `regions_extracted_img` and `index_of_each_map` should be the same, which is not the case with your current code.

I am not against returning special values in case of error to keep the pipeline running, but what you do here may be mlisleading for people.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')

text: Yes I agree, not consistent with doc & code. Ok I will change to return empty one.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/regions/region_extractor.py')
